conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2, we need to analyze the velocity vs. time graph for both objects A and B.
The velocity vs. time graph for object B shows a curve that starts at a higher velocity and then decreases over time.

premise: The acceleration of an object is the change in velocity over time.
conclusion: The acceleration of object B can be calculated by finding the slope of the velocity vs. time graph at any point.
At t1, the velocity of object B is vB(t1). At t2, the velocity of object B is vB(t2).

premise: The formula for acceleration is a = (v2 - v1) / (t2 - t1).
conclusion: The acceleration aB can be calculated using the formula aB = (vB(t2) - vB(t1)) / (t2 - t1).

premise: The slope of the velocity vs. time graph represents acceleration.
conclusion: The acceleration of object B decreases over time because the slope of the graph becomes less steep.

conclusion: The acceleration of object B first decreases and then increases.
